original: EJB stands for Enterprise Java Bean. It is a server-side component to develop scalable, robust and secured enterprise applications in java.  More details...
result: EJB is an acronym for Enterprise Java Bean. It is a vital server-side component that's used to create secure, scalable, and reliable enterprise applications using Java language.

original: There are three types of enterprise bean in java.
result: In Java, there exist three varieties of enterprise beans.

original: Session Bean encapsulates business logic. It can be invoked by local, remote or web service client.
result: A Session Bean is a component that contains business logic and can be accessed by local, remote, or web service clients.

original: There are 3 types of session bean.
result: The session bean can be classified into three categories.

original: A Stateless session bean is a business object that doesn't maintain the conversational state with the client.  More details...
result: A Stateless session bean refers to a type of business object that does not keep any conversational state with the client. It means that every request from the client is handled independently without any prior knowledge of previous requests or interactions.

original: In case the EJB client environment is the same, use @Local annotation.
result: If the environment for the EJB client is consistent, it's recommended to use the @Local annotation.

original: In case the EJB client environment is different, use @Remote annotation.
result: When working with EJB clients that operate in different environments, it is recommended to utilize the @Remote annotation to ensure proper communication between the client and the server. This annotation helps to indicate that the interface is intended for remote access and may require additional configuration to function correctly.

original: Create a stateful session bean.

"Compose a session bean that maintains state information."

original: To signify a stateful bean, use @Stateful annotation.
result: To indicate that a bean has a state, the @Stateful annotation should be used.

original: A Stateful session bean is a business object that maintains the conversational state with the client.  More details...
result: A Stateful session bean refers to a type of business object that preserves the ongoing state of communication with the client. It enables the server to maintain information about the current state of a particular conversation with the client and use it to deliver personalized services.

original: Singleton session bean is instantiated only once for the application. It exists for the life cycle of the application.
result: A singleton session bean is created only once when the application starts up and remains in existence throughout the application's life cycle.

original: Java Message Service is a messaging service to create, send and receive messages asynchronously.  More details...
result: Java Message Service is an asynchronous messaging service that allows users to create, send and receive messages. By using this service, messages can be exchanged between different systems and applications. It offers reliable communication and enables decoupling of communication participants. It is a commonly used method for implementing messaging systems in Java-based applications.

original: In Point to Point model, one message is delivered to one receiver only. Here, Queue is used as a message-oriented middleware.  More details...
result: The Point to Point model is designed to deliver a single message to a designated recipient, utilizing a Queue as a message-oriented middleware.

original: In the Publisher/Subscriber model, one message is delivered to all subscribers. Here, Topic is used as a message-oriented middleware.  More details...
result: The Publisher/Subscriber model distributes one message to multiple subscribers, utilizing a middleware known as Topic. This framework operates on a message-based system.

original: Message Driven Bean (MDB) encapsulates business logic. It is invoked by passing the message. It is like JMS receiver.  More details...
result: A Message Driven Bean (MDB) is a component in Java Enterprise Edition that contains business logic and is triggered by a message. This makes it similar to a JMS receiver.

original: Entity Bean is a server-side component that represents the persistent data. Since EJB 3.x, it is replaced by JPA.  More details...
result: An Entity Bean is a component on the server side that represents the persistent data. In recent versions of EJB (namely EJB 3.x), it has been replaced with JPA.

original: Session Facade is a design pattern to access enterprise bean through the local interface. It abstracts the business object interactions and provides a service layer. It makes the performance fast over the network.
result: The Session Facade design pattern provides a way to access enterprise beans through their local interface, abstracting the interactions with the business objects and providing a service layer. This results in faster performance over network connections.
